MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 2.30 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Anglo-Irish Summit Meeting.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if consideration has been given to when the next Anglo-Irish summit meeting will take place.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach whether he considers that it is appropriate that an Anglo-Irish summit meeting should now take place.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: A Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 1 and 2 together.
No arrangements have yet been made for the next Anglo-Irish summit meeting.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach agree that the good health of Anglo-Irish relations requires frequent meetings between the Taoiseach and the British Prime Minister? Would he further agree that the development of such initiatives as the inter-governmental council, the inter-parliamentary tier, also require frequent meetings? Would the Taoiseach agree that, irrespective of the tenor of any communications he may have had recently from the British Government, we should make all possible haste to have another meeting as soon as possible?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I would point out to the Deputy that of course the ministerial meetings in the context of the Inter-Governmental Anglo-Irish Council are taking place regularly. I would also like to mention that it is not the custom to say in advance when a summit meeting is likely to be held. I agree with the Deputy about the value of these summit meetings. From my own knowledge all such meetings held in recent years have been advantageous and helpful.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Could the Taoiseach say whether he considers that at the forthcoming EEC summit meeting the opportunity would occur to finalise arrangements for a further meeting between himself and the British Prime Minister?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: At the summit meetings in the past it has happened that impromptu informal arrangements could be made during the course of the summit.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach foresee that happening?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: That is possible.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach aware that at the last summit meeting of Prime Ministers it was agreed informally that the next meeting would take place in about six months or so, in fact this spring?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Early spring.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The time in the spring was not defined but it was understood that a meeting would be held certainly by the month of May. While recognising that the advent of new Government in power would involve some postponement of that, would the Taoiseach not agree that it is desirable that the continuity of meetings should not be broken by failing to have another such meeting this side of the summer, at least in the month of July?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I would agree that these meetings are useful and helpful and beneficial. But, as I said, it is not customary to say any length in advance when any particular meeting is going to be held.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: It is not customary to give the date of the meeting for a variety of reasons. But the fact that the meeting is contemplated in the foreseeable future has been known in advance on previous occasions and it is reasonable to ask the Taoiseach does he contemplate and is he taking steps to secure such a meeting this side of the summer, without being more specific than that.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Deputy will understand that the British Prime Minister and British Ministers generally have been, to put it mildly, pre-occupied with the Falklands crisis in recent times and I did not deem it appropriate to raise the question of a meeting until now.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: We can understand the Taoiseach's reticence about raising it at this particular period, but given that the problem has now been substantially resolved would it be the Taoiseach's intention to fix such a meeting this side of the summer break?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I do not wish to comment on that at this stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the amount of flour imports for (a) 1980, (b) 1981 and (c) so far this year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. B. Ahern):
Speaker.P: Imports of flour amounted to 4,144 tonnes in 1980, 7,305 tonnes in 1981 and 4,280 tonnes in the period January-April 1982. April 1982 is the latest month for which data are available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that approximately 1,200 workers are involved in the flour milling industry here and that for the month of April this year the level of imports has doubled over the previous one? Would the Government consider raising at EEC level the possibility of national security being threatened should our own production of flour be limited, so that we could invoke the clause to prevent this alleged dumping of flour on the Irish market?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Aherne Mr. B. Aherne
Speaker.P: The points raised are not of a statistical nature. Although there has been an increase in the April figure, home produced flour accounts for 97 per cent of the consumption of flour in the country. However, I will certainly pass on the points made by the Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Planning Development Control.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Markey Mr. Markey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when local authorities will receive his promised memorandum containing advice and guidelines in relation to planning development control.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Connolly) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Connolly)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Connolly):
Speaker.P: Work on the preparation of a memorandum containing advice and guidelines for local planning authorities on aspects of development control is in progress in my Department. I cannot say at this stage when it will be completed, but there will be no avoidable delay.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Road Development Plan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Markey Mr. Markey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will give details of the works programme in the Road Development Plan for the 1980's where the original projected time scale for starts and completions will not now be met; and the new projections.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: In addition to the regular monitoring of progress on the road development plan which is carried out in my Department, I have initiated an examination which will take account of variations in the pace of implementation of the individual projects involved. When this has been completed, I will be in a position to indicate the updated position of these schemes within the overall plan. In the meantime, Government support for the plan is shown in the substantial level of roads grants which has been made available this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Arising from the Minister's reply to the question from Deputy Markey, has the timetable contained in the plan been adhered to or has there been any revisions from the time schedule set out in the plan?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: There is no change in the timespan. When we get the up-to-date plan of what the progress is, if there have to be alterations in it the Minister will let the House know.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: When does the Minister expect to have the exact information asked for in my question?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: In about three months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Lawlor Mr. L. Lawlor
Speaker.P: One of the major national primary roads needing more attention is the road to the west. As a member of the central local authority——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: A question, Deputy, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Lawlor Mr. L. Lawlor
Speaker.P: There are three county councils involved, Dublin Corporation and Council and Kildare, endeavouring to get this crucial section——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The Deputy will please ask a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Lawlor Mr. L. Lawlor
Speaker.P: Would the Minister take a particular interest in this problem to see if he could get the three local authorities together to improve this national primary?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Is that the road to Galway South?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Lawlor Mr. L. Lawlor
Speaker.P: To Galway East.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I will have that matter looked into but as the Deputy will appreciate, it will depend on the acquisition of land which, I regret to say, is a slow process under the present law. If there is anything I can do to help the three local authorities I will be only too glad to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I would like to raise on the Adjournment the continuing dispute in the District Courts which has rendered the courts inoperative.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I will communicate with the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Are there any plans for the improvement of the Dublin-Navan road, especially between Blanchardstown and Clonee?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I do not have that information here, but if the Deputy puts down a written or oral question I will be only too glad to give him the information.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Would the Minister accept that this is one of the most unsatisfactory roads in the country and which does not seem to have been improved within living memory?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that when the Coalition were in office the roads were very bad and when we came into office we allocated an extra £10 million to alleviate the position. That shows the interest my Government and my Minister have in the road network. We are fully committed to this plan.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: We cannot have a debate on this question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Arising out of the Minister's general remarks is he aware that the road I am talking about — from Clonee to Dublin via Blachardstown — has not been improved since 1932? Would he accept that his party had responsibility for this situation for most of that time?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I will have the matter looked into.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Sherlock Mr. Sherlock
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that at this stage he should allow the local authorities more autonomy or flexibility in regard to the capital expenditure made available for road works? For example, once the capital allocation is made to a local authority it is specified where that money is to be spent, generally on national primary and national secondary roads, but we have a county road system where conditions are deteriorating. Would the Minister allow local authorities flexibility so far as the expenditure of capital is concerned?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I appreciate the point raised by the Deputy but, as he is aware, part of the money allocated comes from the EEC Regional Fund and is for roads which are specified. I have no control over money provided for funds for special projects. Maybe the Deputy is suggesting more flexibility should be given to the block grant. I will have that matter looked at.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kemmy Mr. Kemmy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when he proposes to start work on the completion of the Childers road in Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I understand that work on the remaining section of this road has been in progress for about a year. Road grants in excess of £1.3 million have been allocated to the project, including £400,000 for the current year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kemmy Mr. Kemmy
Speaker.P: I understand road work is going ahead, but I asked when it would be completed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I am unable to say when the road will be completed but the Deputy can take it there will be no undue delay. I do not want to give a date which, because of circumstances, might not be complied with.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: There are no legal difficulties?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: We dealt with that last week.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kemmy Mr. Kemmy
Speaker.P: Would the Minister use his influence to ensure that this work is finished because this is a very important artery road in Limerick?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: The Deputy can take it that I will do everything in my power to see that the work goes ahead.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Surely the Minister has information about the duration of the contract in his brief because nobody signs a contract unless the date is specified?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: No, that is not in my brief.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fleming Mr. Fleming
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will consider amending the legislation covering compulsory purchase orders to allow local authorities to use this procedure to secure sites for libraries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I intend to consider the inclusion of a provision giving local authorities the necessary compulsory acquisition powers in the next suitable local government Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Can the Minister say if the heads of the amending Bill have been drafted in his Department or circulated to members of the Cabinet?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: No, it is only a minor amendment which can be included in the next appropriate Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Owen Mrs. Owen
Speaker.P: Exactly when is it likely that this Bill will be introduced? There are areas in County Dublin where there are no library facilities because the county council cannot provide the land under a compulsory purchase order. I do not think it is good enough for the Minister to say it can be “included in the next appropriate Bill”; I want a date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I am not in a position to give an exact date but I hope it will be early next year.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Fire Stations Construction.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Markey Mr. Markey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will give details of the fire stations which will start construction in 1982, 1983 and 1984; and the estimated capital cost of such.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: The planning and execution of fire station projects is a matter for individual fire authorities and my Department are involved only to the extent of granting approval in principle to a project, which in practice involves the approval of outline plans, and sanctioning any necessary borrowing proposals.

The information available to my Department indicates that eight new fire station projects have commenced or are likely to commence during 1982 in addition to the projects under construction at the beginning of the year. These eight stations and their estimated costs are Rathfarnham, £1 million; Phibsborough, £1.5 million; Bray, £.77 million; Killeshandra, £.1 million; Tinahely, £.22 million; Blanchardstown, £.9 million; Clonmel, phase II, £.77 million and Carrick-on-Suir, £.15 million. It is not possible at this juncture to furnish a schedule of “starts” for 1983-84 which would be in any way definitive or inclusive.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Has the Minister any information regarding the stage of the Cavan station project?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy mean Cavan town?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I am sorry I am unable to give the Deputy that information as I have not got it in my brief.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Will the Minister be good enough to communicate with me on the matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I certainly will.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Water and Sewerage Schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Donnellan Mr. Donnellan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the reason for the delay in sanctioning the Oranmore sewerage scheme, County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: Preliminary proposals for this scheme have been approved, in principle, by my Department. This approval was subject to agreement on the phasing of the scheme and to discussion of the proposed method of sewage disposal between the technical advisers of my Department and the county council. Following these discussions technical investigations have been carried out locally. I understand that the results of the investigations will be submitted to my Department for approval. If these prove satisfactory, the council may proceed to prepare contract documents for the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Donnellan Mr. Donnellan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he is aware of the deplorable state of the building industry in County Galway; and if the Government will provide the necessary finance for the following projects that have been deferred: Galway city water supply scheme; Athenry sewerage scheme; Ballinasloe UDC water supply scheme; and Galway County Council western regional water supply scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: While the building industry nationally is experiencing some difficulties through the effects of recession, the worst of these effects are cushioned by the continuing high level of public investment in the industry which was boosted by the additional provisions of the recent budget. I have no information to suggest that the situation in Galway is different from the national situation.

My Department issued approval to the acceptance of a tender for contract number 3 of the Galway city water supply scheme, to Galway Corporation on 27 January 1982. A Local Loans Fund loan of £400,000 was sanctioned for this scheme on 31 March 1982.

MainHeading.P: The tenders for the remaining three schemes referred to by the Deputy are under consideration in my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment how many units of local authority housing stock in each separate authority area, are not currently in use and have not been used for a period of three months or more.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment how many units of old or fully completed private housing in each county are not currently in use and have not been used for a period of three months or more.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, it is proposed to take Questions No. 11 and 12 together.
The information requested by the Deputy is not available. Information on unoccupied houses, obtained as a result of the 1981 census, will be published by the Central Statistics Office in due course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: My colleague, Deputy Higgins, has a similar question — Question No. 13 — which relates to the availability of information from local authorities to the Department of the Environment. I accept that in all probability the information is not available to the Minister. In view of the inability of the Department to manage efficiently the housing stock, is the Minister prepared to set up a structure that would allow this information to become available?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: Local authorities know the number of houses that are occupied and the number that are unoccupied and any member of a local authority can get that information. The other information requested by the Deputy will be available early in the new year in the census.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I am asking the Minister if he will take steps to give himself and his successors the necessary information to get proper management of local authority housing stock.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: The information is always available at the end of the year. If we request information from local authorities they will give it to us. However, with regard to privately owned houses, the Deputy will appreciate that it might be a costly project for local authorities to get the necessary information. I am all in favour of putting the moneys at my disposal into new housing and other essential items.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Will the Minister not agree that some local authorities have allowed units of their housing stock to be vacant for an undue length of time and have not communicated that information to their members, let alone to the Minister? In view of the fact that all capital moneys for new housing have to come from his Department, does the Minister not consider it prudent and an exercise in good management to make local authorities give this information directly to him on a monthly basis so that he may see just how efficient they are in managing their own housing stock?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I was a member of a local authority for many years. As far as I know, local authorities, and particularly the members of such authorities, know the number of houses unoccupied. As the Deputy knows, there are legal problems involved and there is a limit to the extent I and local authorities can go. However, if I want information regarding the number of unoccupied local authority houses I have no problem in getting it. I might add that the Deputy would have no problem either.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Minister had just said he has not the information.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: The Deputy is talking in a broader context, in regard to all houses unoccupied. At the end of the year that information will be available from the census. It would require local authorities to use many of their resources and would take a considerable time to get the information requested by the Deputy and I do not intend to ask them to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I wish to clarify the rather confused answer given by the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: We cannot have a debate on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I do not intend to debate it. Am I correct in understanding from the Minister that a local authority member can get the information from the authority but I cannot get such information from him?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: A local authority member can get the information from his own authority. I should like to add that I have not received any complaints.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Minister is getting one now.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: That may well be.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kemmy Mr. Kemmy
Speaker.P: When the information sought by Deputy Quinn becomes available to the Minister, will he consider sending a directive to all local authorities to allocate housing and accommodation to people as soon as it becomes available?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: If the Deputy is talking about the allocation of local authority housing, as far as I know local authorities and corporations allocate houses immediately, or very quickly, provided everything is in order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: That is as far as the Minister knows. That was the point of my question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I was a member of a local authority for years and I know the position.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Minister does not know. He has told us he has not the information.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I resent what the Deputy has said.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 13.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Higgins Mr. Higgins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will seek powers to obtain the information referred to in parliamentary questions Nos. 988, 989, 991 and 992 of 26 May 1982 on a regular basis from local authorities in view of the basic need that exists to allocate housing expenditure on the basis of statistically attested need.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: Local authorities submit to my Department annually detailed returns setting out the number of approved applications for local authority housing, giving details of family size and the reason for their approval such as overcrowding, living in unfit conditions, medical grounds and so on. This information enables my Department to examine the comparative urgency of need as between the various housing authorities for capital allocation purposes. The further breakdown suggested by the Deputy is not considered necessary for these purposes and I do not propose to ask local authorities to supply it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Will the Minister agree that while he does not like the process, the Department do not give the money for local authority house building, the responsibility falls on this House? Will the Minister agree that in those circumstances he has given the most utter undemocratic reply to a legitimate question from a public representative? Will the Minister agree that his officials have just said, in effect, that he will get the information privately from local authorities, will look at it in private in the Custom House, will allocate priorities in private in his office and will then come before the Oireachtas and ask us in public to vote moneys for something which has been evaluated in private? In effect is that what the Minister is saying?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: The Deputy may not be aware of the procedures laid down.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: That is why the question is on the Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: The Minister, and the Government, allocate moneys according to the need of each local authority. It is a matter for each local authority to allocate that money to housing schemes that need the go ahead. That is the situation. I am pleased with the way local authorities and corporations have allocated the money for housing and the schemes they have carried out. The only problem I have come up against is that I do not have sufficient money to give to local authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I do not wish to get involved in a debate with the Minister of State about the merits or demerits of spending more money on housing. That is not the point of the question. If Department officials in private can get the information from local authorities upon which they assign a scheme of priorities for the allocation of capital can that information be made available to public representatives in the House? The Minister must agree that in the course of his reply he has conceded that that information is available from local authorities to the Department and I am anxious to know why it cannot be made available at least once a year to Members. This information was refused to Deputy Michael Higgins on the grounds that it was not available in the first instance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I am following procedures laid down for many years. That procedure was adopted by my predecessors. Local authorities submit to me annually detailed returns and the number of applications.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I apologise for pressing this matter but I am sure the Chair will agree that the rights of Members to ask questions and obtain information from Ministers is the point at issue here, not the actual content of the information. Did I understand the Minister to say that as a result of procedures adopted by former Ministers he, the person with specific responsibility, is going to deny this information to public representatives?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I am not denying anything to public representatives and I never did.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Minister has just done so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I am not going to ask officials in my Department to go through all that. I am not willing to ask local authorities to devote time — it would take a lot of time to compile this information — to collecting that information. There has been a lot of abuse of such matters here and we are all aware of the comments in the media about the cost of replying to questions. When I saw the state of local authority housing when I came to office I asked the Minister to allocate more money for local authority housing. I am interested in building houses and giving local authorities money to do so and I do not want to get into little fiddle-dee-dee matters.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: We must move on to the next question. Deputy Quinn has asked seven supplementaries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I wish to ask a final supplementary. This is not a fiddle-dee-dee matter. In his reply the Minister has conceded in the substance, if one blows away the smoke, that the information is made available once a year to his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I should like to ask the Minister of State, on behalf of Members, to make that information available to Members.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I will have a look at that matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gibbons Mr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when a £1,000 grant will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: A grant will be paid when an inspection establishes that the house has been satisfactorily completed and that the other conditions applying to the grant scheme have been complied with.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fleming Mr. Fleming
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will agree to the payment of a house improvement grant towards the cost of an extension which a person (details supplied) in Ballyfermot, Dublin 10, erected recently for urgent medical reasons.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: A grant cannot be allowed in this case because, contrary to a qualifying condition of the scheme, the work had commenced before an inspection of the house was carried out. The applicant was so informed on 28 March 1982.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will arrange to pay a new house grant to persons (details supplied) in Ballybofey, County Donegal, in view of the fact that her family has been living in the house for over 12 months and that all works have been completed; and if he will arrange to pay the grant without further delay.

Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan) asked the Minister for the Environment the reason for refusing a home improvement grant to a person (details supplied) in Castleblayney, County Monaghan.

Speaker.P: This grant was paid in April 1980.

Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): The Minister said that the grant was paid in 1980?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly

Speaker.P: The question is not that long on the Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Can the Minister say if there is any contribution due by the local county council by way of supplementary grant?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: I do not have that information; that is a separate question. The Deputy's question referred to my Department and I am not able to give him the information he has just sought. If I had that information I would be only too glad to give it to him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Will the Minister repeat the date?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Will it surprise the Minister to know that I received a letter from his Department dated 26 May 1981 and the gentleman who wrote it said he was directed by Mr. Raphael Burke, T.D., Minister for the Environment to refer again to representations in connection with a house improvement grant for Mr. Peter Geoghegan, Lisduff, Loughmourne P.O., Castleblayney, County Monaghan. Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: In view of the urgency of the matter, and one thing and another, it was my policy at the time to speed up these things. There could have been duplication in the post. I wanted to get the money out to the applicant and I am sure the Deputy will appreciate that. I should like to know if the Deputy is not happy that the person concerned got the grant?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Questions come from the other side of the House and replies come from the Minister's side.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): I should like to ask the Minister to be patient for a moment and listen to the situation as it has emerged. Am I right in understanding that the Minister told the House that the grant in question was paid on 14 April 1980?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Is the Minister of State aware that I have read out a letter from his Department, dated 13 months later, stating that the file in connection with the grant had gone to the inspector with a view to the payment of the grant, if in order? Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: In view of what the Deputy has said, I will have that matter looked into, but he will appreciate that the information I have is in regard to the payment. I was not aware of that letter being sent to the Deputy — is it May 1980 or May 1981?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): It is May 1981.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): In view of the information which has been given to the Minister for reply to a parliamentary question and in view of the letter that I have, would the Minister not agree that there is slight chaos in his Department?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: The Deputy's colleague was there for a while and he did not clear it up. He left that for me to do.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: He was not locked out of his office.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Question No. 18, please.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Excessive Speeding.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if the question of authorising the provision of ramps by local authorities for the purpose of controlling excessive speeding has been considered; and if measures will be introduced to authorise local authorities to provide ramps at suitable locations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if, in view of the alarming increase in the problem of stolen cars and consequent injury to persons and property, he will make immediate provisions so that local authorities will be empowered to erect experimental ramps and bollards in particularly difficult areas to see if these might alleviate the problem; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Brady, Dublin South-East) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Brady, Dublin South-East)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Brady
Speaker.P: ,Dublin South-East): With your permission, Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 18 and 19 together.

My Department and An Foras Forbartha have been following the progress of experiments in Britain and elsewhere and other modifications of the road surface designed to retard vehicle speeds. There is no statutory authority for the provision of such ramps in this country. Apart from the legal aspects, however, I am not satisfied at this stage that the results of research so far carried out would justify the general adoption of such measures.

MainHeading.P: The exclusion or restriction of traffic by means of bollards or other such measures is a matter for decision by the road authority, in consultation with the Garda authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Is it the position that local authorities do not have a legal right to provide such grants if they wish to do so? Is the Minister aware that speeding causing injury and death is an increasing problem in our towns and on many rural roads and that this measure has been adopted with some success in other countries? Would he give serious consideration to providing these ramps.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I am sympathetic to the Deputy's question. The matter was discussed at great length in Dublin Corporation and the only conclusion that could be arrived at was that perhaps it could be tried out in a particular area on a pilot scheme basis to see if rumble strips or “sleeping policemen” would have some effect. The best way of tackling it would be to try through a local authority to designate some area that would be suitable on an experimental basis. It is an excellent suggestion, but to engage in an overall scheme of introducing rumble strips to slow down traffic might be counterproductive. I said there might be legal aspects that might curtail building such strips, but from my recollection of discussions with Dublin Corporation the feeling was that there would not be any legal obstacles to introducing such rumble strips.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Birmingham Mr. G. Birmingham
Speaker.P: Would the Minister put the legal question beyond doubt, because my recollection is that the view of Dublin Corporation was that such ramps would be helpful and that the the corporation felt they had not got legal powers to provide them? If that doubt exists would the Minister now clarify the situation by introducing the necessary legislation or making the Ministerial order?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I would be happy to take another look at this question. I am sympathetic to the problem. There are various areas which would benefit, from the point of view of safety of school children and so on, from the provision of such ramps.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Birmingham Mr. G. Birmingham
Speaker.P: If an investigation in the Minister's Department reveals that there are legal problems, would the Minister undertake to inform local authorities of the results of such an investigation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): That would have wider ramifications. The best I can do at present is to look at it to see if there are any legal obstructions. I would not be prepared to inform all local authorities the results of such an investigation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: The Minister has left a cloud hanging over this question in relation to the fact that there may be legal aspects to be taken into consideration. Is the Minister in a position to inform the House whether there are any legal aspects to be taken into account or whether he has been advised by his Department that there are no legal complications in the implementation of Deputy Taylor's suggestion?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I have not left a cloud over the issue. I am trying to be helpful. I am sympathetic towards the suggestion and I will further examine it. I cannot give the Deputy a categoric reply to the question he has asked now. That is why I stated to Deputy Birmingham that I would take a further look at it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: Would the Minister encourage the local authority in Dublin city to get involved in a pilot scheme study? I know there are a number of constituencies, including mine, and many housing estates which would welcome involvement in such a scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): This would come through the local authority, but I will certainly give the Deputy that assurance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: Considering the tone of Deputy Taylor's question, which basically sought to find out if the authorisation or provision of ramps by local authorities for the purpose of controlling excessive speeding has been considered, would the Minister inform the House if there are legal complications?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I am happy with the information I have given the House in this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: As the Minister has stated that he intends to have a further look at the matter, would he give special consideration to investigating rear service roadways in built-up areas which are causing concern to residents and local and public representatives?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): Yes, I will do that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Could the Minister elaborate on the Foras Forbartha report? Have they any views on this matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I am not prepared to elaborate any further on this matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Motor Taxation Office.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dublin North-West) Mr. Barrett (Dublin North-West)
Speaker.P: (Dublin North-West) asked the Minister for the Environment if in view of the undue delays that are experienced at present in the Dublin motor taxation office due to insufficient staff, consideration will be given to increasing the staff and to introducing more flexible hours of opening to the public.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): The appropriate number of staff in motor taxation offices is a matter for the local authorities concerned to consider in the first instance. There are no proposals before my Department from Dublin Corporation seeking increases in staff numbers in the Dublin motor taxation office. The hours of opening of motor taxation office are matters for the individual local authority concerned to arrange.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Cosgrave Mr. M. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware of recent reports that people are not receiving their tax discs through the post and is he aware of the reason for this?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I am aware that there have been problems in this area, but I feel the computerisation of vehicle registration will go a very long way to alleviate this and will have a definite impact in decreasing the workload generally. I am hopeful that a very dramatic improvement will take place in the registration and taxation office as a result.

As regards items being lost in the post or otherwise, I think it would be more beneficial to be specific in cases like that which could actually be examined. I do not say that you will have absolute perfection in the administration of any office. There is a total of 125 people operating in the taxation office and I am of the opinion that they are doing their job as efficiently as possible. However, I believe computerisation will improve that situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dublin North-West) Mr. Barrett (Dublin North-West)
Speaker.P: (Dublin North-West): Has the Minister any personal experience of the situation existing in the Dublin motor tax office at present? I had a personal experience of 150 to 200 people being in the queue and I waited over two hours to have my car taxed. Would the Minister not agree that there should be more flexible hours in order to alleviate the problem? Sometimes, as I am aware, people have to lose a half day from work to have a car taxed? This represents a loss to industry and a loss of earnings to those concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I am familiar with the office concerned. What might help to speed up efficiency would be the giving out of discs to people as they queue up. This has proved a more efficient system. We shall just have to look at the position again and hope that it can be improved further.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Cosgrave Mr. M. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: If a person has not received a tax disc and is held up by gardaí and asked to produce a tax disc within ten days, how will that person stand?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): The Deputy would realise, I think, that the gardaí concerned would show every possible consideration in such an event. I know it is not the Deputy's intention to dramatise or sensationalise the matter but if there are isolated cases where this has happened——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Cosgrave Mr. M. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: They are not isolated cases; there are hundreds of people not receiving discs.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I should like to know about them and investigate them further.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Wandering Animals Legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dublin North-West) Mr. Barrett (Dublin North-West)
Speaker.P: (Dublin North-West) asked the Minister for the Environment if he intends to amend the legislation in relation to animals wandering on roads with a view to increasing fines.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): As stated in reply to Questions Nos. 484 and 485 of 29 October 1981, there is no specific proposal for amending roads or road traffic legislation on this subject. The main legal difficulty in this area has been the immunity from full civil liability of the “keepers” of straying animals. This question has now been fully reported on by the Law Reform Commission and the Government are arranging to have the report examined by the Department concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Birmingham Mr. G. Birmingham
Speaker.P: Could the Minister give us the date of the report of the Law Reform Commission to the Government?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): 11 June 1982. The Law Reform Commission submitted two reports to the Taoiseach dated 11 June 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Birmingham Mr. G. Birmingham
Speaker.P: Did the earlier report from the Law Reform Commission not make clear the fact that legislation in this area was wholly unsatisfactory and that has been with the Government for a matter of years?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): It has been unsatisfactory, I agree, on the two main issues — this question of the immunity by which the “keeper” is protected and the second question of whether or not to make the keeper of the animal strictly liable for injuries caused by any fault on the part of the keeper. The Department of Justice as the Deputy realises, would be the Department concerned in this instance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: In view of the fact that there is a draft Bill attached to the final report from the Law Reform Commission, is there determination on the part of the Government to introduce amending legislation at the earliest possible date?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I would agree to give consideration to that and recommend it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Cosgrave Mr. M. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: As the Minister is aware, this is a very serious problem in the city of Dublin, could the Minister tell me how many pounds we have in Dublin city and how many are in operation at this time?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I do not have that information to hand.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Cosgrave Mr. M. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: Perhaps the Minister would forward it to me?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I certainly will.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the cost to the Exchequer of the additional housing for Dublin as outlined in the arrangement between Deputies Haughey and Gregory-Independent and announced in the Dáil on 9 March 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): The Minister for Finance in his budget speech of 25 March 1982 stated that an additional £14 million will be made available to Dublin Corporation for house construction, especially for urban renewal purposes, in the current year bringing the total allocation from £62 million to £76 million. The additional capital will enable the Dublin Corporation to boost work in progress by 650 dwellings and employment by about 500 at the end of this year compared with the end of 1981.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: Has any of that money yet been paid to the local authorities?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I would not have that information for the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that not a penny has in fact been paid, that interest payments on the debt arising at local authority level are of the order of £20,000 per week and that the local authorities are naturally very concerned about this? Would the Minister please ensure that whatever moneys have been promised will be paid as quickly as possible?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): Yes. I am not quite sure in the context of the reply what the Deputy is actually indicating. I must compliment him on his adroitness in asking supplementary questions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Would it be within the brief of Dublin Corporation to expend portion of the money on the construction of houses in county areas or would that money be confined to inner-city housing construction?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): It will not apply only to inner-city houses. I have a complete list of the starts here with which I shall be happy to furnish the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Are there any in County Dublin?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): I should have to go through them all. I shall be happy to communicate with the Deputy about the matter later.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): I understood the Minister to say that the money involved——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): The total allocation goes from £62 million to £76 million.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Did I understand the Minister to say that this is to be applied towards building houses and could he say when these houses will start or what arrangements have been made regarding them?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East) Mr. Brady (Dublin South-East)
Speaker.P: (Dublin South-East): Yes. I certainly can. It is quite a detailed list and I have it before me. In the inner-city, which is designated northside and south-side, there are seven such starts projected for 1982 — I am sure the Deputy is speaking about those.
