I appreciate that the Minister may not have the information now at his disposal but I am using this occasion to bring the matter to his attention. An investigation should be carried out to see that these things do not happen and something must be immediately done to have that office development occupied. After all, the Government are spending a considerable amount of money on electrifying the Howth-Bray railway line which would make it an extremely——

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Jim Tunney
Speaker.P: I am sorry, Deputy, I must return to the ringside terminology and count you out.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): I have just one more point to make. I am sure that the Minister will agree that Dún Laoghaire is a very attractive place to have office development, particularly for a Government Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: I am grateful for this opportunity to make a few remarks on this very important topic, and I am glad that the Deputy raised this matter. I tried to raise the subject with the Ceann Comhairle at 3.30 p.m. today, specifically mentioning the nameless unoccupied building in Dún Laoghaire. Unfortunately, I was ruled out of order. Deputy Enright's proposition, however, was accepted.

There is an arguable economic theory that civil service office and semi-State office accommodation should be leased. I was a member, quite a number of years ago, of the Committee of Public Accounts and when this question of leasing office accommodation arose I took the view, which I still hold, that these office blocks should be brought by the various organisations on behalf of the civil service and the semi-State bodies. I had hoped the view I expressed ten years ago in this regard would have been acted on so that State and semi-State bodies would now be sitting on quite valuable properties. That has not happened. I reiterate my views that these office blocks should be bought by the occupiers.

There is an office block on the sea front in picturesque Dún Laoghaire which is vacant and which should be occupied as a matter of urgency. The decision not to continue with the lease was taken by the last Coalition Government. Though I agree with Deputy Enright and Deputy Barrett, it is still important to get the record correct. We want to continue the economic well-being of the community in Dún Laoghaire: we do not want to see valuable office blocks being left vacant, as they were during the lifetime of successive Governments. The BIM operation is fragmented and spread: they occupy a number of buildings, and we should like to see BIM centralised in Dún Laoghaire. Therefore, I am asking the Minister to give us some idea of what will be done with this white elephant, standing in stark nakedness on the sea front in Dún Laoghaire. I hope the Minister will examine it. I again thank Deputy Enright for having given me time to speak.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. Barrett, Clare) Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. Barrett, Clare)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. Barrett
Speaker.P: ,Clare): The Office of Public Works are responsible for the provision of accommodation for the civil service as a whole, with a few minor exceptions. The Office has a continuous demand from Departments for office accommodation much of which must be met by renting premises in the open market. When premises become available on the market and are generally suitable to meet a particular need the Office of Public Works must move in immediately to open negotiations.

Such office blocks come on the market in an incomplete state internally. They are essentially shells completed on the outside but with minimum finishes internally. This is the practice to enable prospective lessees to adapt the space available to their own requirements. As is the norm in the property market, to secure premises on lease, liability for rent must be accepted from the date of agreement of terms. This is the position the Office of Public Works find themselves in when they must lease an office block to solve a particular problem.

A number of steps must then be taken to transform the shell to finished office accommodation. The first step is to get a full and detailed brief on the requirements of the Department in question. Depending on the location of the building and many other considerations, the Department must decide on which sections of staff are to be moved and how they are to be grouped in the new building to give the best results from an organisational point of view. The Department must then document the specific facilities they require for those units of staff. This process of necessity takes time, involving as it usually does consultation with unions and staff associations. While the Office of Public Works are at all times available in an advisory capacity, it cannot proceed with planning until a full brief is established.

MainHeading.P: Once the brief has been received, the Office of Public Works must convert it into a detailed floor plan for the approval of the Department. This is to ensure that the working space available will be used to best advantage to enable the Department to satisfy themselves that all their requirements will be met. At this juncture, oftimes alterations have to be made involving preparations of revised plans.

Once agreement has been reached on layout plans, the Office of Public Works must proceed with the preparation of contract documents covering architectural and engineering works, invite tenders and place contracts in accordance with Government contract procedures. These contracts can be substantial, and in the case of a large office block a fitting out contract can be in the range of several hundred thousand pounds. Works of this scale and variety could take a year or more to complete.

The provision of telephones, floor covering and furniture must follow. The Department then have the problem of movement of staff and papers to the building with minimum disruption to their operations. Such movement of staff may have to be scheduled to avoid critical dates for certain services. All of this process is necessary to ensure that the building will serve to maximum efficiency for the duration of the lease, usually 35 years, and to comply with Government contract procedures.

This is undoubtedly a complicated process but it is difficult to see how any of it can be dispensed with. Nevertheless, it seems to me that the time taken to establish briefs fully constitutes too large a part of the overall process.

In the case 4-5 Harcourt Road, which was occupied by three separate Departments, receipt of briefs varied from November 1980 to November 1981, although each Department's requirements were requested at the same time. Preparation and agreement of plans and contract documents and placing of contract took five months. Completion of work took seven months. The briefing period is indicative of the difficulty which Departments have in determining their precise requirements. We must appreciate that this is not in the normal course of these Departments' activities and therefore can pose particular problems. Perhaps in this area there may be room for improvements and I propose to have this aspect of the matter examined.

The BIM development in Dún Laoghaire was referred to by Deputy Andrews. The Office of Public Works were not involved in that. Perhaps the Department of Posts and Telegraphs could give an answer in regard to it. I was asked what our demands for accommodation are. As of now, we are not involved in any negotiations in regard to office space but that does not mean the Office of Public Works will not get requests from Departments in the future. We are not involved at the moment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: How much space have the Office in hand at the moment?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Clare) Mr. Barrett (Clare)
Speaker.P: (Clare): In Harcourt Road we have 117,000 square feet. I have not got a figure for the total space.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: Would the Minister ascertain that and furnish it to me?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Clare) Mr. Barrett (Clare)
Speaker.P: (Clare): I will do that.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance when work will commence on the building of the new garda station at Ballingeary, Macroom, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry
Speaker.P: Tenders for the erection of a new Garda station and residence at Ballingeary have been received. It is not possible at this stage to say when work will commence but there will be no avoidable delay.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fleming Mr. Fleming
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance when traffic control measures, including the provision of roundabouts, will be introduced on the main road in the Phoenix Park.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry
Speaker.P: A number of traffic control measures, involving the provision of white lines and of additional speed limit signs, have recently been introduced on the main road in the Phoenix Park. It is also intended to erect a temporary demountable roundabout at the Phoenix Cross on the main road. Arrangements will be made for this work when the type of lighting at the roundabout itself and along the approach roads leading to the roundabout has been settled. Subject to the temporary roundabout proving satisfactory, it is proposed to have permanent roundabouts erected at all the four junctions on the road.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Dublin Primary School.

The further arrangements for the erection of the school are the responsibility of the chairman of the board of management of the school. It is understood from the Chairman's architect that work on the site commenced on 8 June 1982.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Farm Building Grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if new low cost buildings will qualify for grants under the present modernisation schemes for farm buildings in view of the enormous number of cattle kept outdoors during the winter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: Grant aid is available under the farm modernisation scheme and the programme for western development for various types of cattle housing such as kennels, byres, loose houses, cubicle houses and slatted houses constructed to approved specifications. The housing may be constructed from traditional materials such as concrete, timber and galvanised iron or from approved synthetic materials. Houses constructed mainly from timber are also eligible.

MainHeading.P: The regulations governing slurry storage and disposal and the requirements of the planning authority must of course be met.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Keeffe Mr. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture whether he is aware of a ruling made by the Farm Development Service in January 1979 reducing the level of grants for development farmers with a break in the sequence of their farm accounts; whether he is further aware that this ruling was not publicised until December 1981 and that in the meantime many farmers had been advised to change their accounting dates for tax and other reasons; and whether he will ensure that those affected by this retrospective ruling will not be penalised.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: Under the terms of the farm modernisation scheme, farmers in the “development” category are obliged to keep farm accounts for each year of their farm plan and to submit the required extract to the chief agricultural officer each year. This has been a requirement of the scheme since its introduction in February 1974 and the consequences of non-compliance have been emphasised on a number of occasions since then.

Before an applicant is accepted into the “development” category he is required to furnish a written undertaking that he will comply with all the conditions of the scheme including the conditions relating to farm accounts. Where a farmer fails to honour his commitments in regard to the keeping of farm accounts he forfeits entitlement to the rate of grant aid appropriate to the “development” category.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will sanction the allocation requested by ACOT for educational and training purposes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: The Deputy is, I presume, referring to the extra funding sought by ACOT to implement a proposed new certificate in farming programme. No provision for this activity was made in ACOT's 1982 grant-in-aid and so no funds are available for this purpose in the current year. The concept is a laudable one, but as its implementation would involve the State in substantial additional and continuing cost, I have decided that the introduction of the programme should be considered in the context of the national development plan for agriculture.

In addition development farmers participating in the farm modernisation scheme in this area are eligible for: (a) an additional 5 per cent for land improvement; (b) an additional 10 per cent grant for farm structures and; (c) grants of up to 40 per cent of the cost for approved imvestments on the farm in tourist or craft projects.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the proposals he has to prevent further sheep being killed by marauding dogs.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs Hussey Mrs Hussey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if, in view of the serious loss of sheep and lambs caused by marauding dogs on farms throughout Ireland, he will review the present system of dog control as a matter of urgency.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose taking Questions Nos. 507 and 508 together.

Existing legislation provides comprehensive powers and measures for the control of dogs, including that aspect of particular concern to my Department, which is the protection of sheep from attack by marauding dogs. The question of the more effective implementation of these powers and measures is being examined by my Department in conjunction with the other Departments involved, namely, the Departments of the Environment, Justice and to a lesser degree, Finance. The matter is also being considered in the Advisory Council on Animal Health.
One of the objectives of these on-going deliberations will be to strengthen the implementation of those measures concerned with the protection of sheep from dog attacks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dukes Mr. Dukes
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the average length of time between the submission of an application for grant-aid under the farm modernisation scheme to a local ACOT office and the final payment of the grant.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Lehihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: The farm modernisation scheme is operated jointly by ACOT and the farm development service. Matters relating to applications for participation in the scheme, classification, drawing up farm plans etc. are the responsibility of the local ACOT office. When the ACOT process is completed, the approval of specific on-farm projects for grant purposes, and the administration of grant payments are handled by the farm development service.

If no unusual circumstances arise, the average length of time from the submission of an application to ACOT until authority is given by the FDS to proceed with the proposed work is about six months. The execution of the work is the sole responsibility of the applicant. The time taken for completion can vary substantially. The time between the satisfactory completion of the work and payment of the grant is about six weeks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connaughton Mr. Connaughton Mr. O'Brien Mr. O'Brien Mr. Hegarty Mr. Hegarty
Speaker.P: and Mr. Connaughton asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will consider allowing farmers who have part-time jobs and who are in severe financial difficulties to participate in the interest subsidy schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Lenihan) Brian (Snr.) Lenihan
Speaker.P: A part-time farmer is eligible for the national 5 per cent interest subsidy scheme provided that his income from an occupation outside farming is less than the national comparable income and provided that the family farm income is not in excess of that figure. The EEC 5 per cent interest subsidy scheme and the reduced interest scheme for farmers in severe financial difficulty are confined to farmers who derive at least 50 per cent of their income from farming and spend more than 50 per cent of their working time on farming activities. Accordingly, farmers with part-time jobs who meet these criteria are not excluded from the benefits of these schemes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Protection of ESB Moneys.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism if he considers that the arrangements that are made by the ESB to recover money owed to them by companies in receivership are adequate to protect the interest of consumers in general; and, if not, the steps he proposes to take to ensure that the ESB are adequately protected.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley):
Speaker.P: Section 98 (1) of the Companies Act, 1963, applies to a receivership the provisions of section 285 of that Act in relation to preferential payments in a winding up. The ESB are not listed among the preferential creditors and they are, therefore, in the same position as other unsecured creditors.

I do not see any reason to alter this position particularly since, as I indicated recently during the debate on the Companies (Amendment) Bill, 1981, any lengthening of the list of preferential creditors would damage the interests of employees where a company is being wound up or is in receivership.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism if the cost of industrially used fuel oil is higher in Ireland than in other European countries; if so, if he will illustrate the differences by comparing Irish prices with those obtaining in other specific European countries; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley):
Speaker.P: I have taken the Deputy's question to refer to heavy fuel oil.

MainHeading.P: The price data available to me on comparative European prices is extremely tentative and does not provide a reliable basis for me to furnish accurate information in reply to the Deputy's question.

From calculations which my Department have made, based on the latest oil company prices available from the EEC and our own estimates of the incidence of taxation on these products in the member states, it appears that the Irish consumer price is higher than the other member states prices with the exception of Denmark. Unfortunately, because of the unreliability of the data and because I understand there is no consistency of approach by member states as to the prices reported, I am not in a position to give a price comparison as requested by the Deputy. At best, all I can say is that our calculations show Irish prices to be about 5 pence per gallon above those in the UK, but also 5 pence per gallon below those pertaining in Denmark.
I must emphasise that these figures are estimates.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism if he will bring the price of compounds for animal use under the umbrella of the National Prices Commission and prevent price increases which have been occurring over the last number of years without any consultations with farmers throughout the country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley):
Speaker.P: The price of animal compounds already falls within the area of scrutiny of the National Prices Commission. The price of compounds is subject to comprehensive monitoring on a continuous basis by the commission. These arrangements were introduced following consultation with farming organisations and there is regular contact with representatives of the farming community in the matter. The results of the monitoring exercise have not yielded evidence of unwarranted price increases within the animal compound sector.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism whether he intends to amend the relevant regulations to ensure that all food, confectionery and other similar consumer items will carry a full description in intelligible and accurate language of the contents of such products; if he is satisfied with the present position in this respect; and the controls or monitoring he operates at present to ensure that the public interest and public health are safeguarded.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley):
Speaker.P: My Department are at present finalising draft regulations to implement EEC Directive 79/112, known as the Food Labelling Directive. These regulations will require the labels of prepacked food to give a clear and easily understandable indication of, among other things, the ingredients of the product. I expect to be making the regulations shortly and I am confident that they will represent a significant advance in the level of information available to consumers.

With regard to the Deputy's reference to public health, I understand that the Department of Health, through the health inspectorate, carries out an elaborate food sampling programme with a view to ensuring that public health is safeguarded, and that this operates satisfactorily.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sale of Music Tapes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism if he will ask the Director for Consumer Affairs to investigate the sale of music tapes to the Irish consumer which are sold as being original recordings when they are not and as being of good quality when in fact they are of such an inferior quality that they damage tape recorders.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley):
Speaker.P: As regards false or misleading information, the Director of Consumer Affairs has the power in any case which is brought to his notice to make inquiries and to initiate legal proceedings as appropriate. If the Deputy has any details of such a case, I would suggest that he pass these to the Director.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Insurance Companies Settlements.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism if he will deal with insurance companies which delay unduly in complying with court awards of damages to insured persons; if he has a means of monitoring non-compliance; and the number of complaints he has received of such non-compliance in each of the past three years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. O'Malley):
Speaker.P: I have power to suspend or revoke the licence of an insurance company which has failed to pay within one month a claim adjudged to be due. Since, obviously, such action would have the most serious consequences and as the licensee has the right of appeal to the High Court, I would have to be completely satisfied that it was justified having regard to all the circumstances.

MainHeading.P: Compliance with court judgments is not monitored by my Department nor would it be practicable to do so. Complaints from the public about insurance companies' practices are, however, taken up by my Department with the company concerned. There appears to be little general dissatisfaction with the payment by insurers of amounts awarded by the courts. Only eight such complaints have been received in the past 12 months and they were all satisfactorily disposed of by the companies concerned. While I am unable to give figures for earlier years, the experience of the past 12 months can be taken as representative of the annual level of complaints of this nature made to my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Donegal-Derry Cross-Border Study.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make an up-to-date report on the progress of the Donegal/Derry cross-border study; and if he will list the schemes (a) which have been completed, (b) now being dealt with and (c) yet to be started.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins):
Speaker.P: In the joint North-South progress report on this area, which was issued by the two Governments in June 1980 and a copy of which is in the Dáil Library, a detailed account was given up to that stage of progress being made in the implementation of the Derry-Donegal Communications Study which was completed in November 1977. On 18 November 1981, in a written answer to a question from Deputy Mervyn Taylor, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs gave an updating of the 1980 progress report so far as Donegal was concerned. The following is an updating of the progress outlined in the 1980 joint progress report and in the former Minister's written answer of 18 November 1981.
(A) Roads (County Donegal)
The first stage of the road programme for North Donegal as recommended by the consultants is being implemented in full.

MainHeading.P: Road grants allocated for work in the Donegal section of the study in 1982, including supplementary grants allocated from the Government's additional capital investment of £470,000 on the Letterkenny/Derry road (National Primary N13); £175,000 for the Stranorlar/Letterkenny route; £55,000 for strengthening works at various locations on the N15 and N56; £10,000 for road signs on the National Primary routes, and £100,000 for improvement works on proposed regional roads. In addition to these grants totalling £810,000, a general block grant of £1,212,100 has been allocated to Donegal County Council for 1982 for work, at the discretion of the council, on roads other than national roads.
The detailed position regarding the road improvements in Donegal is as follows:
Inter-Urban Roads
(i) Letterkenny-Pluck Cross, National Primary Route N13.

Outline design has been completed, a detailed ground survey has been carried out and detailed road design is almost complete. Subject to the availability of finance it is planned to commence construction in 1984.
(ii) Bridgend-Pluck Cross, National Primary Route N13.
Two of the remaining sections of this route are included in current improvement programmes: (a) Newtowncunningham By-Pass; (b) Bridgend By-Pass.
Scheme (a). Land acquisition proceedings in progress.
Scheme (b). Final design being completed. Land acquisition proceedings in progress.
(iii) Letterkenny/Stranorlar, National Secondary route N56. Work will continue on the improvement of this route near Bullock Park this year.
(iv) Urban through routes
Letterkenny

A scheme linking the Letterkenny/Pluck Cross and Letterkenny/ Kilmacrenna roads has been in progress since 1977 and was opened to traffic early in 1979. Designs have been prepared and land acquisition negotiations are well advanced for the improvement of the Portbridge/Kilmacrennan road at its junction with the Railway road and the bus station. Work will commence on this section this year and it is hoped to complete the relief road scheme from Portbridge to the Kilmacrennan road by the end of 1983.
(B) Telecommunications

To date 14 exchanges in North Donegal have been converted to automatic working. It is expected that another eight exchanges will be converted this year. 60 per cent of all subscribers in North Donegal will then have automatic service. Work towards converting the remaining exchanges is proceeding and all exchanges will be converted by 1984.
The Sligo-Letterkenny radio link will be in service by mid 1982.
Direct dialling between most automatic exchanges in the Republic and all Northern Ireland exchanges will be provided this year.
(C) Public Passenger Transport

Assistance is being provided to the Lough Swilly Bus Company through the agency of CIE in consideration of the continued provision by the company of road passenger services in the North Donegal area. Thirty seven secondhand buses, which have been acquired at a cost of £200,000, have been leased by CIE to the company. The cost of these buses is recouped to CIE by the Exchequer, half the cost coming from the Non-Quota Section of the European Regional Development Fund. In addition, CIE are making payments to the Swilly Company to assist with cash flow requirements arising out of losses being incurred on road passenger operations.
The question of continued assistance to the Swilly Company is now being reviewed with a view to submission to Government.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - South Africa Rugby Tour.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will express his disapproval of the reported tour to South Africa of a rugby team composed of players from Britain and Ireland in which there are six Irish players reportedly included; if he will arrange a meeting with the Irish players involved to make his views known to them; and if he will urge them not to participate in such a tour.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins):
Speaker.P: I have seen reports that some Irish rugby players have been or are to be invited to participate in an invitation team to visit South Africa in July.

The views of the Government on sporting contacts with South Africa with specific reference to rugby football were made very clear during the controversy surrounding the IRFU tour in South Africa last year. It remains the Government's view that sporting contacts of this kind serve only to support the apartheid system; a system that denies fundamental human rights to the vast majority of South Africans on the basis of their skin colour. The Olympic Principle of NonDiscrimination in Sport cannot be satisfactorily observed in a situation in which the organisation of many sports in South Africa, including rugby football, continues to be largely determined by the organisation of society on the racially segregated lines of the apartheid system.
The Government do not believe that participation by Irish players in the reported tour would be in the interests of justice in South Africa, of Ireland's international reputation, or of Irish sport.

They hope that Irish players will not participate in the tour and that any players invited to take part will consider carefully their decision in the light of the Government's policy on sporting contacts with South Africa and in the light of the clear public concern expressed on the issue last year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins):
Speaker.P: The EEC Council in its decision of 25 July 1978 agreed to provide a fixed contribution of 46 million European units of account (approximately £31 million) towards the cost of increasing Irish fisheries inspection and surveillance capacity in the period 1 January 1977 to 31 December 1982. Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether he envisages any reform in the law to permit wives who hold joint passports with their husbands to travel without being accompanied by their husbands.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins):
Speaker.P: The practice regarding issue of an Irish joint or family passport originated in general international usage to which Ireland has conformed. Such a passport is intended as a special facility to accommodate a husband and wife travelling together who do not find it necessary to hold separate travel documents and do not wish to incur the additional fees involved in obtaining two passports rather than one. In fact relatively few family passports are now issued as most people prefer to hold their own individual passports. I agree, however, that the distinction involved in the present practice is unnecessary and I am arranging that in future a joint or family passport may be issued in the name of either spouse as desired.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if any explanation has been given by the United Kingdom Government as to the reason for the delay of ten days in accepting responsibility for the sinking by one of their submarines of the trawler Sharelga.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. G. Collins):
Speaker.P: The British authorities have stated in reply to our request for an explanation of the delay that the captain of the submarine in question had been unaware that his vessel had been involved. They have further explained that it was only as the investigation by our authorities continued that there were indications that a British vessel might have been involved, and it was necessary to have a full investigation before they could inform us with certainty that one of their submarines had caused the sinking. According to the British authorities these circumstances also accounted for the fact that no effort had been made at the time to ensure the safety of the crew of the Sharelga.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Transfer of Department Section.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bellew Mr. Bellew
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Public Service the proposals there are to transfer a section of a Government Department to Dundalk, County Louth.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald) Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald):
Speaker.P: When the Government announced the decentralisation programme in October 1980, Dundalk was the designated centre for a section of the Department of Posts and Telegraphs. The number of staff to be transferred was approximately 300. After the 1981 general election the incoming Government placed the programme under review and there it remained throughout their term of office.

With our return to office the programme has been reactivated and arrangements are in hand for its early implementation. Already tenders have been invited for the provision of the necessary office accomodation in five of the designated centres. In the case of Dundalk planning has been delayed due to the difficulty of finding a suitable site. A site is now in prospect and the planning stage will commence as soon as the site is secured.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Public Service if he is aware of the United Kingdom Government report (Cmnd 8504) on “Administrative Forms in Government”; if he will initiate a similar review here as to whether forms issued to the public by Government Departments are as well designed and as simple as they should be; and if he generally favours the recommendations of the United Kingdom report.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald) Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald):
Speaker.P: I am aware of the publication mentioned. I strongly support the efforts which are being constantly made to ensure that all official forms are easily dealt with. This involves both simplifying their content and improving their presentation.

A great deal has already been done in this field by Government Departments. I consider that more remains to be done and so I have recently taken steps to have a special review made of forms and documents to try and make them as effective as possible. Any improvements suggested by any Member of this House, or by anyone else will be warmly welcomed and will receive serious and sympathetic consideration.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Public Service Pension Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Public Service what the provision in the budget estimates for 1982 in respect of the public service pension scheme would be if the scheme were funded on an actuarial basis.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald) Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Gene Fitzgerald):
Speaker.P: As public service pension schemes are currently financed on a pay-as-you-go basis rather than from a fund the actuarial information that would be needed in order to provide the answer to the Deputy's question is not available. I can, however, say that the information available to me in respect of the pension terms of established civil servants indicates that the actuarial cost of those terms is about 18 per cent of payroll. On this basis, the cost of funding the year of service in question would be about £87,000,000. Since the pay bill for established civil servants represents some 27 per cent of the public service pay bill, the cost of public service pensions on a corresponding basis would be considerably in excess of £87,000,000 but it is not possible to give an accurate estimate of that cost because of differences between the pension terms, age structures, etc. of the various groups involved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Wilson):
Speaker.P: The need for an automatic full-time service to serve the Moneygall-Dunkerrin area is fully appreciated and the works necessary to provide it have been approved. The building to house the automatic exchange has been completed and the installation of the automatic equipment has been contracted for. The contractor's plans envisage that installation of equipment will commence early in 1983. Allowing for the time taken by the contractor to install the equipment and for testing by Departmental staff, conversion to automatic working could be expected in the autumn of 1983. Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Wilson):
Speaker.P: The new State-sponsored bodies will be liable in respect of service rendered by their staff as from the day the bodies are set up. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Community Centre.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the application for a community centre grant which was lodged by Cloghanover Social Club, Headford, County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Professor O'Donoghue) Minister for Education (Professor O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: Cloughanover Social Club was not among the projects selected for capital grant assistance under the community, youth, recreational and employment programme.

Details of the youth employment scheme were issued to the club on 11 March 1982 and the club was invited to complete and return the application form if it considered that the scheme would be of assistance to it. To date my Department have not received an application for assistance under this particular scheme on behalf of this club.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will confirm his commitment to provide a post-primary school in Castleknock, County Dublin within three years; if he will outline in detail the stages that have to be gone through before the school is built and opened; if he will list the deadlines for each of these stages and the date of the opening of the school; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Professor O'Donoghue) Minister for Education (Professor O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: It is intended that the new post-primary school proposed for Castleknock will be provided by September 1985. Consultants for the project will be appointed within the next few weeks. The stages then required for the completion of the project are (1) Architectural planning, 12 months (approx); (2) Seeking of tenders and awarding of contract, 2-3 months; (3) Construction period completion and handover, 15-18 months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bellew Mr. Bellew

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Professor O'Donoghue) Minister for Education (Professor O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: My Department agreed in principle in January 1982 to the extension of Harestown national school. The Commissioners of Public Works have recently reported that it is feasible to provide the additional accommodation on the existing school site and the chairman has been so informed. The plans for the project will be prepared by the commissioners.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Moynihan Mr. Moynihan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he is satisfied in regard to the availability of a dental service for medical card holders.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Woods) Minister for Health (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Dental services for medical card holders are provided by the health boards in two ways as follows: (1) At dental surgeries run by the dental staff of the health boards. Those catered for are mainly the aged, the handicapped, nursing and expectant mothers and eligible adolescents, i.e. those who are between the ages of 12 and 16 years and are dependants of medical card holders; (2) By dentists in private practice under the ad hoc arrangement whereby they provide dental services for medical card holders on behalf of the health boards. Those who receive treatment from the dentists in private practice are generally adults other than those treated by the health boards' own dental staff.

Due to the limited financial resources available to them this year some health boards found they were not in a position to provide as much money as they would wish for the ad hoc scheme. In some cases a priority basis for the issue of authorisation for treatment was introduced. Where a priority system is in operation persons who are not in the priority groups may experience delays in obtaining treatment. However, services for the relief of pain are an absolute priority for all eligible persons.
I am satisfied with the level of the dental service available to medical card holders having regard to the present shortage of finance for the health services generally.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Insurance Fund.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare who has been assigned responsibility for the administration, care and policy in relation to the use of the Social Insurance Fund here and in each other EEC country for which such information is available.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The Social Insurance Fund comprises a current account and an investment account. The current account is managed and controlled by the Minister for Social Welfare and the investment account by the Minister for Finance. The statutory provisions in this respect are contained in section 122 of the Social Welfare (Consolidation) Act, 1981.

MainHeading.P: Somewhat similar arrangements apply in Great Britain and Northern Ireland where a single Department of State is responsible for the provision of benefits from a single fund.

A wide range of agencies and funds are however involved in the provision of social security benefit in other member states of the EEC. In many instances there are separate agencies and funds for the different forms of benefits and for different classes of contributors. The competent authorities for social security in these States are the appropriate Government Ministers but information is not readily available on the detailed manner or degree of control exercised by the competent Ministers over the various agencies and funds. Information on the basic organisation and method of financing of these social security systems is given in an EEC publication Comparative Tables of the Social Security Systems in the Member States of the European Communities. A copy of the most recent edition of this publication, which sets out the situation at 1 July 1980, is available in the Dáil Library.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare how many officers of inspector rank in his Department are involved in investigating social welfare abuses in (a) Dublin and (b) the rest of the country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: All officers of my Department are required as part of their normal duties to be on the alert for possible abuses of the social welfare system and to refer for investigation any case in which suspected irregularities come to their notice. This applies in particular in the case of outdoor staff of whom there are 60 social welfare supervisors, 249 social welfare officers and eight inspectors of agents. These officers are mainly concerned with the investigation of means in the case of means tested benefits and ensuring that the provisions of the Social Welfare Acts in relation to social insurance are complied with. Twenty eight officers are, however, specifically engaged on the investigation of abuses of the various schemes. Of the 28 officers, ten are based in Dublin and 18 cover the rest of the country. Although most of the officers do not have the official title of inspector their duties consist essentially of inspection work.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason unemployment assistance has not been paid to a person (details supplied) in Goresbridge, County Kilkenny, as the application was made some eight weeks ago and the person has no income.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods

This is the maximum rate appropriate to a single person with nil means living in a rural area. All arrears of unemployment assistance due to the person concerned have been paid to him and further weekly payment continue to be made as they fall due.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason unemployment benefit has not been paid to a person (details supplied) in Graiguenamanagh, County Kilkenny, who has been unemployed since 20 May 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The person concerned made a claim to unemployment benefit on 25 May 1982. Inquiries were necessary to determine whether he satisfied the statutory conditions for the receipt of benefit. These inquiries were recently completed and the claim has been allowed at the weekly rate of £51.75. Payment of all arrears due will be make this week. Further weekly payments will continue to be made as they fall due.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Aylward Mr. Aylward
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if the full rate of unemployment assistance is being paid to a person (details supplied) in Graiguenamanagh, County Kilkenny, who is married with five dependent children.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The person concerned is in receipt of unemployment assistance at the weekly rate of £61.90, being the maximum rate appropriate to a married man with five qualified children living in a rural area namely, £75.35, less means of £13.45 derived from the profit from land rented by him. He is, therefore, receiving the full amount of unemployment assistance to which he is entitled. To be entitled to the maximum rate of unemployment assistance a person must be assessed with “nil” means.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Aylward Mr. Aylward
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason unemployment assistance has not been paid to a person (details supplied) in Graiguenamanagh, County Kilkenny, who has no income, is unable to find work and has forwarded all details to his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The person concerned applied for unemployment assistance in March 1982. His application is, however, still under consideration by a deciding officer who is not satisfied that the person concerned satisfies the condition for the receipt of unemployment assistance which requires that he must be genuinely seeking work. The person concerned has been written to in this regard and when a reply is received from him his application will be decided without delay. In the meantime it is open to him to apply to his local community welfare officer for supplementary welfare allowance pending a decision regarding his unemployment assistance entitlement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Aylward Mr. Aylward
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason disability benefit has not been paid to a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny since 3 May last as the person had been in hospital for several weeks.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods

It has been established that the claimant was admitted to hospital on 3 June 1982 and payment of disability benefit has accordingly been restored from 3 May 1982. All payment due to 26 June 1982 has now issued.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Creed Mr. Creed
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence the reason all the equipment referred to in the reply to Parliamentary Question No. 201 of 29 April 1980 has not yet been acquired; the reason for the delay in ordering the two helicopter-carrying ships and the five maritime aircraft; and if the money provided for this purpose by the EEC will not now be paid as it covered the period to the end of last year only.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power
Speaker.P: The equipment referred to forms part of a programme for the provision of resources to cater for fishery protection measures. Under this programme three vessels have been built already and brought into service, a helicopter-carrying vessel has been designed and an order for the first such vessel was placed with Verolme Cork Dockyard Ltd. last month. A provision of £1 million is included in the Defence Estimate this year for a down-payment on the purchase of two maritime helicopters. The question of acquiring a further helicopter-carrying vessel will be considered as the programme develops.

A number of different types of aircraft for maritime surveillance purposes are being evaluated with a view to deciding the most suitable type. Two Beech Super King aircraft were purchased to enable the Air Corps to carry out surveillance in the meantime.
The period for recoupment from EEC funds continues to the end of the present year. The question of seeking an extension is being pursued.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hegarty Mr. Hegarty

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power
Speaker.P: As I indicated in reply to a question on 18 May 1982, certain site investigations are now being carried out to determine the type of foundations which would be required for a bridge. The necessary provision to meet the cost of these investigations is included in the Vote for Defence for 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Creed Mr. Creed

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power
Speaker.P: The organisation and role of An Slua Mhuirí are kept under constant review. The programme of providing new equipment, including dinghys for each company, is being continued.
I am satisfied that these continued improvements will attract adequate numbers of suitable personnel to An Slua.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Creed Mr. Creed
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence the amount of money received from the EEC; the amount claimed and paid by his Department for the equipment referred to in reply to parliamentary Question No. 201 of 29 April 1980; and if he will give details of the equipment purchased and its cost.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power
Speaker.P: Claims totalling £18,863,846 out of an expenditure of £21,340,210 (inclusive of VAT) were made by my Department in respect of the period 1 January 1977 to 31 December 1980. Refunds totalling £17,971,141 were made by the EEC. A claim amounting to £83,963 has been made in respect of the year 1981.

Since 1 January 1977 three vessels of the Deirdre class — LE Emer, LE Aoife and LE Aisling— have been launched and a contract was placed on 23 April 1982 for the construction of a new design vessel with helicopter-carrying facilities, Two Beech aircraft were leased and subsequently purchased in December 1979.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Creed Mr. Creed
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if he is aware of the very high turnover of personnel in FCA units, the high cost of uniforms and equipment and the low percentage of FCA personnel who attend training nights and annual training and the steps he intends to take to improve the situation and make the FCA more attractive.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power
Speaker.P: The strength of the FCA at the end of the 1981 was close on 22,000. The high strength level over the years is regarded as most satisfactory for a force which is both voluntary and part-time and I am glad to say that the continuing buoyancy in numbers has not been affected by the turnover of personnel.

The attendance at weekly training sessions and field days varies from centre to centre but the overall pattern is satisfactory. The average numbers attending annual training, which is about 10,500, is also satisfactory and is a tribute to the dedication and commitment of FCA personnel.

Having regard to the very valuable service given by FCA personnel I am satisfied that the financial outlay on uniforms and equipment is well spent. I am sure the Deputy will agree that the new style uniform recently introduced has done much to enhance the image of An Forsa.
I am satisfied that the FCA are a very attractive force for young men interested in military activities and it is my intention to ensure that it will continue to be so.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Creed Mr. Creed

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power
Speaker.P: This matter raises fundamental questions in relation to military discipline and the question of what modification by way of clarification or otherwise can be introduced is still under consideration.
I would point out, however, that members of the Defence Forces have always been free to consult with their public representatives regarding questions other than those relating to service matters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Creed Mr. Creed

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Power) Patrick Power
Speaker.P: In general the lands administered by my Department are required for military purposes. I am, however, prepared to have any specific proposal on the lines indicated in the question considered on its merits.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. Reynolds):
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Industrial Development Authority that it has provided two 24,000 sq. ft. factories and a 6 × 3,000 sq. ft. cluster unit on its 22 acre Industrial Estate at Killarney. One of these 24,000 sq. ft. factories is occupied by a German company, Schaef, who will employ over 100 people at full production and three of the 3,000 sq. ft. units are also occupied. In addition a 24,000 sq. ft. factory is under construction on the site for Killarney Electronics who will employ over 400 people at full production.
Construction will begin on a further 24,000 sq. ft. factory, to be financed by the private sector, later this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Murphy Mr. Murphy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Energy if he proposes to meet with interested persons and associations to discuss matters pertaining to the development of the studio facilities at the National Film Studios of Ireland, Bray, County Wicklow.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. Reynolds) Albert Reynolds
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. Reynolds):
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose to take Questions 854 and 855 together.

It is my intention that the National Film Studios shall be disposed of to a purchaser who will undertake to maintain and develop their film-making facilities. I will be prepared to give very careful consideration to constructive and realistic proposals for development of the facilities, within this framework. If proposals of this nature are put forward I will endeavour to have them pursued by whatever discussion or consultative process is most appropriate and practicable.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Irish Steel Holdings Ltd.

Speaker.hpid: Miss M. Barry Miss M. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Energy if he will outline the Government's intention regarding the future of Irish Steel Holdings Ltd.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. Reynolds) Albert Reynolds
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. Reynolds):
Speaker.P: The Dáil recently approved a grant of £25 million to Irish Steel Limited. In addition to this I have introduced a Bill in the Dáil to increase the authorised share capital of the company from £25 million to £50 million, and to increase the amount of borrowings which I may guarantee from £60 million to £75 million.

The Government are fully aware that these measures will not ensure the long-term future of Irish Steel, but they are necessary to enable the company to operate while consultants study its prospects. These consultants will be appointed in the near future, and following their report, the Government will decide on the long-term future of the company.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Naughten Mr. Naughten

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Raphael Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Raphael Burke):
Speaker.P: In 1980-1981, local authorities carried out assessments of total housing requirements. These assessments did not distinguish between private and local authority housing. An analysis of the assessments is now practically completed. On 30 March 1982 I indicated in Dáil Éireann that I intend to press ahead with the publication of a White Paper on Housing around the end of this year, columns 907 and 908 of Official Report. The White Paper will set out the analysis of national housing requirements and the Government's programme to meet those requirements in terms of finance, housing production and the quality of housing and its environment. The White Paper will also distinguish between housing provided by local authorities and by the private sector.

The Government have set a production target of 6,000 local authority houses per annum. Sufficient funds to achieve this target will be made available through the public capital programme and will be allocated to individual housing authorities on the basis of comparative urgency of need for funds to finance their local authority housing programmes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hegarty Mr. Hegarty
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he is aware that people living in urban areas do not qualify for the essential repair grant; and if he is prepared to rectify this anomaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Raphael Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Raphael Burke):
Speaker.P: I am aware that the essential repairs grants scheme has, since its introduction in 1963, been confined by statute to houses located in county health districts. This followed from the basic objective of the scheme which was to enable local authorities to give assistance for the carrying out of minimal repairs to prolong the lives of houses occupied by elderly persons where there would be no continuing need for a house after their death.

I have no proposals at present to amend the regulations in order to extend the essential repairs scheme to urban areas nor, indeed, am I convinced that this would necessarily be the best way of dealing with the problem of unsatisfactory housing conditions of some elderly persons in urban areas.

The Governments concern in this regard is however evidenced by the fact that a special provision of £1 million was made in this year's budget to finance an emergency programme to be undertaken by a task force to improve the living conditions of elderly persons living in insanitary or unfit accommodation. I am satisfied that this approach is more flexible and sympathetic than a formally regulated grants scheme and that it will result in speedy action being taken where necessary on behalf of those living in unacceptable conditions.

Speaker.P: As in respect of other rivers there are existing national and local statutory regulations designed to conserve the salmon stocks in the River Slaney.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Parole and Sentences Review Procedures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will give details in relation to the procedures for (a) parole and temporary or early release and (b) for reviewing procedures for long sentences, particularly in relation to prisoners serving life sentences; the remission to which they are entitled; and the length of time in prison after which such a prisoner can apply for parole.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice by whom decisions regarding parole etc. are made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose to take Questions Nos. 954 and 957 together.
Prisoners or persons in detention serving sentences of one month or more may earn remission of up to one quarter of sentence by industry and good conduct.

MainHeading.P: Under section 2 of the Criminal Justice Act, 1960 prisoners or persons in detention may be given what is called temporary release. A prisoner or detainee may apply for temporary release at any time. The general policy is that the case of a prisoner serving a sentence of more than four months is reviewed as a matter of course on a regular, multi-disciplinary, basis whether or not he or she asks for early release.

I accept responsibility for the release of all persons under the section quoted above. I am satisfied that each case is considered carefully having regard to all the relevant factors including the wellbeing of the offender and his family and the safety of the public. There has been attempted intimidation of officers in my Department by criminals and their associates and I am not prepared to put officers at risk by giving details which would tend to identify officers working in this area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice whether the period spent under sentence of death and the poor prison facilities available for women prisoners is taken into account when reviewing long-term sentences.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: Any factors considered relevant, including special tension and the physical environment in the prison, are taken into account in the course of the detailed appraisal which such cases receive.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Birmingham Mr. G. Birmingham
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will express his Government's concern at the reported increase in the incidents of personation during the recent general election; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that 65 cases of personation were reported to the Garda in respect of the 1982 general election. Prosecutions have already been taken in some of these cases and others are under investigation. There were 51 reported cases in respect of the 1981 general election, resulting in 15 prosecutions and 14 convictions, and 20 reported cases in respect of the 1977 general election, resulting in 13 prosecutions and 12 convictions. I should make it clear that the Minister for Justice has no function in relation to the taking of prosecutions.

Quite clearly any increase in breaches of the law is a matter of concern to me and to the Government. The question of what can be done about this type of offence is another matter. The Garda authorities say that personation is difficult to detect especially in urban areas where personation agents and other officials, including gardaí, cannot identify all the voters on the list of electors. They are further of the opinion that more use of personation agents by candidates would assist in the elimination of this offence. The recently enacted prevention of Electoral Abuses Act has clarified the provisions of the electoral law in relation to the offence of personation.

The authorities are not in a position to extend the present local patrolling arrangements for the Malahide area but they say that there are of course arrangements for providing a police service for the area from the district headquarters at Coolock when the station at Malahide is closed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sale of Sling-shot Toy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the action he intends to take in relation to the free sale in this country of a sling-shot toy, the arrival of which in this country was recently reported extensively in the media; whether he is satisfied with the easy availability of such a weapon; and the steps he has taken or intends to take in that respect.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: While the law contains restrictions on the sale or possession of firearms, it does not apply itself directly to the sale or possession of many other items that could in certain circumstances be misused, through negligence or otherwise, such as catapults, sling-shots, cross-bows or even knives, though of course the carrying of an offensive weapon by a person intending to commit a felony is an offence.

As regards sling-shots, I understand that more types than one are available in other countries but I am informed by the Garda that they have no reports that would suggest that the particular type of sling-shot that has appeared on the market here poses a serious problem. They are, however, keeping the matter under review.

The Deputy will appreciate the difficulties of legislating against specific weapons or articles which could be used offensively or dangerously but which also have legitimate or innocent uses, all the more so as new items tend to come on the market from time to time, but, when an opportunity presents itself, I propose to consider whether there should be some strengthening of the law about offensive weapons generally.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of applications that have been made to the courts to dispense with the consent of a natural mother to the making of an adoption order under section 3 of the Adoption Act, 1974; and the number of such applications that have been (a) granted and (b) refused.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: To date 25 such applications have been made to the High Court and 24 of them have been disposed of. Eighteen of the applications were successful, three of which have been appealed to the Supreme Court and are awaiting hearing in that court. In six cases no order was made and the remaining case is listed for hearing in July.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Garda Stations Strength.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when it is envisaged that the Garda strength in Santry, Coolock, Whitehall and Clontarf Garda stations, Dublin, will be increased; and by how many persons in each case.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of gardaí stationed in (a) Coolock and (b) Raheny Garda Stations, Dublin; and the plans to increase the number in these stations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 969 and 970 together.

The detailed deployment of members of the force is a matter to be decided primarily by the Garda authorities and the strength assigned to the various stations is reviewed from time to time to take account of changing needs and circumstances. The strength at Coolock and Raheny stations on 21 June 1982 was 80 and 50, respectively.

I am informed by the Garda authorities that in the period from 16 April 1982, when a number of newly-trained recruits took up duty, to 21 June 1982 an additional ban-garda was assigned to Whitehall station, the strength at Coolock station was increased by one sergeant and three gardaí and the strength at Raheny station by two ban-ghardaí.

The Garda authorities are not in a position at present to provide for any further increases in strength at any of the five stations mentioned in the questions but the needs of the areas will be reviewed according as additional manpower currently in training becomes available for assignment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice how many civil decrees of annulment were granted by either the High Court or the Supreme Court in 1981; and how many nullity petitions were issued in that year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: The number of civil decrees of annulment granted by the High Court in 1981 was eight. No decrees of annulment were granted by the Supreme Court in 1981. The number of nullity petitions issued during 1981 was 21.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dukes Mr. Dukes
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when Garda strength will be increased in the Leixlip area of County Kildare, which is served from Lucan, as the present strength is inadequate.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: The detailed deployment of members of the force is a matter to be decided primarily by the Commissioner and the precise arrangements for policing particular local areas are made by or in consultation with the local Garda officers.

The Garda authorities have informed me that the existing arrangements for policing the Leixlip area make the best use of Garda resources. They also state that, having regard to overall resources and other demands on Garda services, they are not in a position at present to increase the strength at Lucan station but that the matter will be reviewed according as the additional manpower, at present in training, becomes available for assignment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if and when it is intended to establish a Garda station at Donaghmede, Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Cosgrave Mr. M. Cosgrave
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will provide a Garda station in the area of Donaghmede, The Donaghies, Grange Abbey and Millbrook Estate, Raheny, Dublin, in view of the increased incidents of vandalism in these areas.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Owen Mrs. Owen
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice whether he intends to establish a Garda station for the Donaghmede area, Dublin 13.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose to take Question Nos. 973, 974 and 975 together.

The area of Donaghmede, the Donaghies, Grange Abbey and Millbrook Estate, Raheny, is one of a number of areas in and around Dublin where there is a local demand for a new Garda station. The difficulty about providing extra Garda stations, apart from difficulties associated with getting suitable sites and the high building costs involved, is that manning them absorbs Garda manpower which might possibly be used more effectively on patrol duty in the area.

The area referred to is at present serviced by Coolock and Raheny Garda stations and it is intended to allocate a number of additional gardaí to these stations at the earliest possible date. This will provide a better Garda presence over the whole area covered by these stations and may obviate the need for a separate station in the Donaghmede vicinity. The situation, however, will be kept under review to see whether the measure which I have outlined will adequately meet the police needs of the areas in question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will arrange to publish the guidelines laid down by the Adoption Board and issued to each society under the Adoption Act, 1953.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: It would be for the Adoption Board and the adoption societies to decide whether any communication between them ought to be made public. I can understand that members of the public may be interested in knowing what procedures may have been recommended to societies by the board or agreed between them and I am forwarding a copy of the Deputy's question to the board for their attention.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: As this is a matter concerning the entitlement to expenses of a member of the Garda Síochána, which is a disciplined force, I do not consider it appropriate to deal with it in a reply to a parliamentary question. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Duleek (Meath) Policing.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 978 and 979 together.

MainHeading.P: The precise arrangements for policing individual areas are made by the Garda authorities. The authorities have informed me that the current strength at Duleek is the maximum that can be provided at present having regard to overall resources and other demands on Garda services. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Monitoring of Cults' Activities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Keeffe Mr. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice whether the activities of cults are monitored in Ireland; and whether there are any plans to control their activities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: My concern and that of the Garda Síochána in relation to the activities of any person or group is in regard to possible criminal activity. Any such behaviour which comes to the notice of the Garda Síochána is investigated as a matter of course. I have no proposals to control the activities of cults.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Transfer of Gardaí.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he has either ordered, requested or discussed with the Garda Commissioner the transfer of gardaí from areas outside Dublin, particularly Cork, to Dublin, thereby lowering the level of Garda protection in those areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Doherty) Sean (Longford-Roscommon) Doherty
Speaker.P: Since taking office as Minister for Justice, I have had a number of discussions with the Garda Commissioner about a variety of matters affecting the Garda Síochána, including the overall strength and deployment of the force.

As already announced, I am satisfied that there is need for a substantial increase in Garda strength and I have therefore made arrangements to speed up recruitment and provide the necessary additional accommodation and facilities at the training centre at Templemore.

MainHeading.P: Pending completion of training of the new recruits already in Templemore and to be brought in during the rest of the year and following a review of the needs of various areas, the Commissioner is arranging for the redeployment of up to 100 existing members to take account of current needs and with a view to making optimum use of available resources.

In redeploying members of the force, it is inevitable that Garda strength will be reduced in some areas in which, in the professional judgment of the Garda authorities, the need for current levels of strength is not as great as in other areas. The precise arrangements made for policing particular areas are, of course, matters for the Garda authorities and I accept their professional judgment in matters of that kind. I am informed by them that no reduction in Garda strength in Cork is proposed. The Deputy can be assured that the Garda needs of all areas will again be reviewed according as the additional manpower now in training and being recruited becomes available for assignment to the various centres.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Markey Mr. Markey
